eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Jeroen Erkens, Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: FollowObjectsWithCamera
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Change the zoom and position of the camera to keep all instances of an object (or object group) on the screen.
description: This action is meant to be run on every frame (i.e: usually you would use it without conditions, or just conditions picking the appropriate objects to track).
- Use an object group to track multiple objects.
- Only run on one layer at a time.  If multiple layers need to move the same way, create events that copy CameraX, CameraY, and CameraZoom values.
- This can also be used on a single object instance to move the camera smoothly.

eventsFunctions.description: Change the zoom and position of the camera to keep all instances of an object (or object group) on the screen.
eventsFunctions.name: FollowObjectsWithCamera
eventsFunctions.sentence: Move camera on layer _PARAM6_ to keep instances of _PARAM1_ on the screen. Use a margin of _PARAM2_px horizontally and _PARAM3_px vertically. Use a zoom between _PARAM4_ and _PARAM5_.  Move the camera at a speed of _PARAM8_

events.comment: Set default values if nothing is entered
Set initial values based on an object instance.  This is used as a valid starting point for comparisons, so it doesn't matter which instance is used.

Loop through every instance of object (or object group) and determine the max position values used for left, right, top and bottom.
Record the height and width of the objects that are on the edges.  These values will be used to increase the camera viewport to include the entire object.
Move camera to the center location
Zoom in or out to keep all object instances on screen
Adjust zoom to stay within min/max values

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Sway
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: A behavior to make objects (like grass) sway randomly.
description: Use the Sway behavior to make multiple instances of an object sway at different times. For example, this can give a grass object an animated look that is always changing and is different to the other grass objects.
![Imgur](https://i.imgur.com/dOyTgbN.gifv)
Please note:
This behavior uses *For each object* events so be aware of slow downs that may occur from many instances of Sway objects.
The behavior works best if both the *Center* and *Origin* points are at the base of the object.
Sway works by:
- angling (pivoting) the object to the left and right while also changing its Y scale up and down
- the angle and Y scale tween durations will take a random amount of time from a range of values
- it's this random tween duration that creates the unique movement pattern for each instance of the object.
How to use:
- set left and right angles (degrees) for the object to sway to
- for equal sway on each side set the left angle to the negative number of the right angle
- eg. set left angle to -5 and right angle to 5
- set a minimum and maximum Y scale amount for the object to stretch and shrink to
- set to 1 for no change, more than 1 for stretching and less than 1 for shrinking
- set a range for the angle and Y scale tween times (seconds)
- the tweens will take a random amount of time between the minimum and maximum values

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Sway multiple instances of an object at different times - useful for random grass swaying.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: Sway

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Ahnaf30e
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: FPS
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Adds expressions and a behavior to get and display the game FPS.
description: Adds expressions to get the current FPS and a behavior to display the current FPS easily.

The FPS, Frames Per Second, describes how many times in the last second your game got updated. An update consists in running all the behaviors, objects, and events sheet code, before rendering the new game state into the game window. The higher the FPS, the more it manages to update in a second, influencing how fluid and performant your game looks.

eventsFunctions.description: Return your game's current FPS count.
eventsFunctions.name: FPS

eventsFunctions.description: Return your game's current FPS count, with more control over rounding.
eventsFunctions.name: PreciseFPS

parameters.longDescription: This tells how many numbers after the period should be shown.
parameters.name: accuracy

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Makes a text object display the current FPS.

propertyDescriptors.label: The prefix before the FPS count
propertyDescriptors.name: prefix

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: PANDAKO-GitHub
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: MousePointerLock
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: This behavior removes the limit on the distance the mouse can move and hides the cursor.
description: This behavior removes the limit on the distance the mouse can move and hides the cursor.
For example, a user can rotate or continue to manipulate an object by moving the mouse endlessly.
Without the pointer lock, the rotation or operation will stop the moment the pointer reaches the edge of the browser or screen.
Game players don't have to worry about leaving the gameplay area or accidentally clicking on another application that moves the mouse focus away from the game.
Locking the pointer locks `MouseX()` and `MouseY()` expressions.
Use `MovementX()` and `MovementY()` instead.

eventsFunctions.description: Get the movement of the pointer on the X-axis.
eventsFunctions.name: MovementX

eventsFunctions.description: Get the movement of the pointer on the Y-axis.
eventsFunctions.name: MovementY

eventsFunctions.description: Lock the mouse pointer to hide it.
eventsFunctions.name: RequestPointerLock

eventsFunctions.description: Unlocks the mouse pointer and show it.
eventsFunctions.name: ExitPointerLock

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the mouse pointer is locked.
eventsFunctions.name: isPointerLocked
